qas.question: What acidic salts were commonly found in the early types of paper produced?
Early papermakers added alum to help in what process?
How was rag paper superior to the early types of paper made using alum?
What did a lot of the wood pulp made from paper contain?
What was took out of paper to assist in sizing?
What is more of an issue with papers made with non acidic additives?
What is becoming less prevalent when making paper?
By what are the acid fibers that make up paper hydrolyzed?
What acidic salts were uncommonly found in the early types of paper produced?
Late papermakers added alum to help in what process?
How was rag paper inferior to the early types of paper made using alum?

context: Much of the early paper made from wood pulp contained <b3_0>significant amounts of <b8_0>alum<b8_0/><b3_0/>, a variety of aluminium sulfate salts that is significantly acidic. <a0_0><b4_0>Alum<b4_0/><a0_0/> was added to paper to assist in <a1_0><b9_0>sizing<b9_0/><a1_0/>, making it somewhat water resistant so that inks did not "run" or spread uncontrollably. Early papermakers did not realize that the alum they added liberally to cure almost every problem encountered in making their product would eventually be detrimental. The <b7_0>cellulose<b7_0/> fibres that make up paper are hydrolyzed by acid, and the presence of alum would eventually degrade the fibres until the paper disintegrated in a process that has come to be known as "slow fire". Documents written on rag paper were significantly <a2_0><b10_0>more stable<b10_0/><a2_0/>. The <b6_0>use of non-acidic additives<b6_0/> to make paper is becoming more prevalent, and the <b5_0>stability<b5_0/> of these papers is less of an issue.
